trans-unit.source: Manage Key Vault using CLI | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage Key Vault using CLI | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use this tutorial to automate common tasks in Key Vault by using the CLI
trans-unit.target: Use this tutorial to automate common tasks in Key Vault by using the CLI

trans-unit.source: Manage Key Vault using CLI
trans-unit.target: Manage Key Vault using CLI

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault is available in most regions.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault is available in most regions.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Key Vault pricing page](../../../../pricing/details/key-vault/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Key Vault pricing page](../../../../pricing/details/key-vault/).

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Use this tutorial to help you get started with Azure Key Vault to create a hardened container (a vault) in Azure, to store and manage cryptographic keys and secrets in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Use this tutorial to help you get started with Azure Key Vault to create a hardened container (a vault) in Azure, to store and manage cryptographic keys and secrets in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through the process of using Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface to create a vault that contains a key or password that you can then use with an Azure application.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through the process of using Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface to create a vault that contains a key or password that you can then use with an Azure application.

trans-unit.source: It then shows you how an application can then use that key or password.
trans-unit.target: It then shows you how an application can then use that key or password.

trans-unit.source: **Estimated time to complete:** 20 minutes
trans-unit.target: **Estimated time to complete:** 20 minutes

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial does not include instructions on how to write the Azure application that one of the steps includes, which shows how to authorize an application to use a key or secret in the key vault.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial does not include instructions on how to write the Azure application that one of the steps includes, which shows how to authorize an application to use a key or secret in the key vault.

trans-unit.source: Currently, you cannot configure Azure Key Vault in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Currently, you cannot configure Azure Key Vault in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Instead, use these Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface instructions.
trans-unit.target: Instead, use these Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface instructions.

trans-unit.source: Or, for Azure PowerShell instructions, see [this equivalent tutorial](key-vault-get-started.md).
trans-unit.target: Or, for Azure PowerShell instructions, see [this equivalent tutorial](key-vault-get-started.md).

trans-unit.source: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see [What is Azure Key Vault?](key-vault-whatis.md)
trans-unit.target: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see [What is Azure Key Vault?](key-vault-whatis.md)

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: A subscription to Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: A subscription to Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have one, you can sign up for a [free trial](../../../pricing/free-trial).
trans-unit.target: If you do not have one, you can sign up for a [free trial](../../../pricing/free-trial).

trans-unit.source: Command-Line Interface version 0.9.1 or later.
trans-unit.target: Command-Line Interface version 0.9.1 or later.

trans-unit.source: To install the latest version and connect to your Azure subscription, see [Install and Configure the Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface](xplat-cli.md).
trans-unit.target: To install the latest version and connect to your Azure subscription, see [Install and Configure the Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface](xplat-cli.md).

trans-unit.source: An application that will be configured to use the key or password that you create in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: An application that will be configured to use the key or password that you create in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: A sample application is available from the [Microsoft Download Center](http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=45343).
trans-unit.target: A sample application is available from the [Microsoft Download Center](http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=45343).

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see the accompanying Readme file.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see the accompanying Readme file.

trans-unit.source: Getting help with Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface
trans-unit.target: Getting help with Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you are familiar with the command-line interface (Bash, Terminal, Command prompt)
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you are familiar with the command-line interface (Bash, Terminal, Command prompt)

trans-unit.source: The --help or -h parameter can be used to view help for specific commands.
trans-unit.target: The --help or -h parameter can be used to view help for specific commands.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, The azure help [command] [options] format can also be used to return the same information.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, The azure help [command] [options] format can also be used to return the same information.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following commands all return the same information:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following commands all return the same information:

trans-unit.source: When in doubt about the parameters needed by a command, refer to help using --help, -h or azure help [command].
trans-unit.target: When in doubt about the parameters needed by a command, refer to help using --help, -h or azure help [command].

trans-unit.source: You can also read the following tutorials to get familiar with Azure Resource Manager in Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface:
trans-unit.target: You can also read the following tutorials to get familiar with Azure Resource Manager in Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface:

trans-unit.source: How to install and configure Azure Cross-Platform Command Line Interface
trans-unit.target: How to install and configure Azure Cross-Platform Command Line Interface

trans-unit.source: Using Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface with Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Using Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface with Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Connect to your subscriptions
trans-unit.target: Connect to your subscriptions

trans-unit.source: To log in using an organizational account, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To log in using an organizational account, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: or if you want to log in by typing interactively
trans-unit.target: or if you want to log in by typing interactively

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The login method only works with organizational account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The login method only works with organizational account.

trans-unit.source: An organizational account is a user that is managed by your organization, and defined in your organization's Azure Active Directory tenant.
trans-unit.target: An organizational account is a user that is managed by your organization, and defined in your organization's Azure Active Directory tenant.

trans-unit.source: If you do not currently have an organizational account, and are using a Microsoft account to log in to your Azure subscription, you can easily create one using the following steps.
trans-unit.target: If you do not currently have an organizational account, and are using a Microsoft account to log in to your Azure subscription, you can easily create one using the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Login to the Login to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/), and click on Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Login to the Login to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/), and click on Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: If no directory exists, select Create your directory and provide the requested information.
trans-unit.target: If no directory exists, select Create your directory and provide the requested information.

trans-unit.source: Select your directory and add a new user.
trans-unit.target: Select your directory and add a new user.

trans-unit.source: This new user is an organizational account.
trans-unit.target: This new user is an organizational account.

trans-unit.source: During the creation of the user, you will be supplied with both an e-mail address for the user and a temporary password.
trans-unit.target: During the creation of the user, you will be supplied with both an e-mail address for the user and a temporary password.

trans-unit.source: Save this information as it is used in another step.
trans-unit.target: Save this information as it is used in another step.

trans-unit.source: From the portal, select Settings and then select Administrators.
trans-unit.target: From the portal, select Settings and then select Administrators.

trans-unit.source: Select Add, and add the new user as a co-administrator.
trans-unit.target: Select Add, and add the new user as a co-administrator.

trans-unit.source: This allows the organizational account to manage your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: This allows the organizational account to manage your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Finally, log out of the Azure portal and then log back in using the new organizational account.
trans-unit.target: Finally, log out of the Azure portal and then log back in using the new organizational account.

trans-unit.source: If this is the first time logging in with this account, you will be prompted to change the password.
trans-unit.target: If this is the first time logging in with this account, you will be prompted to change the password.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using an organizational account with Microsoft Azure, see [Sign up for Microsoft Azure as an Organization](sign-up-organization.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about using an organizational account with Microsoft Azure, see [Sign up for Microsoft Azure as an Organization](sign-up-organization.md).

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to specify a specific one to use for Azure Key Vault, type the following to see the subscriptions for your account:
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to specify a specific one to use for Azure Key Vault, type the following to see the subscriptions for your account:

trans-unit.source: Then, to specify the subscription to use, type:
trans-unit.target: Then, to specify the subscription to use, type:

trans-unit.source: For more information about configuring Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface, see [How to Install and Configure Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface](xplat-cli.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about configuring Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface, see [How to Install and Configure Azure Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface](xplat-cli.md).

trans-unit.source: Switch to using Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Switch to using Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: The Key Vault requires Azure Resource Manager, so type the following to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode:
trans-unit.target: The Key Vault requires Azure Resource Manager, so type the following to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode:

trans-unit.source: Create a new resource group
trans-unit.target: Create a new resource group

trans-unit.source: When using Azure Resource Manager, all related resources are created inside a resource group.
trans-unit.target: When using Azure Resource Manager, all related resources are created inside a resource group.

trans-unit.source: We will create a new resource group 'ContosoResourceGroup' for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: We will create a new resource group 'ContosoResourceGroup' for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter is resource group name and the second parameter is the location.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter is resource group name and the second parameter is the location.

trans-unit.source: For location, use the command `azure location list` to identify how to specify an alternative location to the one in this example.
trans-unit.target: For location, use the command `azure location list` to identify how to specify an alternative location to the one in this example.

trans-unit.source: If you need more information, type: `azure help location`
trans-unit.target: If you need more information, type: `azure help location`

trans-unit.source: Create a key vault
trans-unit.target: Create a key vault

trans-unit.source: Use the `azure keyvault create` command to create a key vault.
trans-unit.target: Use the `azure keyvault create` command to create a key vault.

trans-unit.source: This script has three mandatory parameters: a resource group name, a key vault name, and the geographic location.
trans-unit.target: This script has three mandatory parameters: a resource group name, a key vault name, and the geographic location.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you use the vault name of ContosoKeyVault, the resource group name of ContosoResourceGroup, and the location of East Asia, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you use the vault name of ContosoKeyVault, the resource group name of ContosoResourceGroup, and the location of East Asia, type:

trans-unit.source: The output of this command shows properties of the key vault that you've just created.
trans-unit.target: The output of this command shows properties of the key vault that you've just created.

trans-unit.source: The two most important properties are:
trans-unit.target: The two most important properties are:

trans-unit.source: **Name**: In the example this is ContosoKeyVault.
trans-unit.target: **Name**: In the example this is ContosoKeyVault.

trans-unit.source: You will use this name for other Key Vault cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You will use this name for other Key Vault cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: **vaultUri**: In the example this is https://contosokeyvault.vault.azure.net.
trans-unit.target: **vaultUri**: In the example this is https://contosokeyvault.vault.azure.net.

trans-unit.source: Applications that use your vault through its REST API must use this URI.
trans-unit.target: Applications that use your vault through its REST API must use this URI.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure account is now authorized to perform any operations on this key vault.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure account is now authorized to perform any operations on this key vault.

trans-unit.source: As yet, nobody else is.
trans-unit.target: As yet, nobody else is.

trans-unit.source: Add a key or secret to the key vault
trans-unit.target: Add a key or secret to the key vault

trans-unit.source: If you want Azure Key Vault to create a software-protected key for you, use the `azure key create` command, and type the following:
trans-unit.target: If you want Azure Key Vault to create a software-protected key for you, use the `azure key create` command, and type the following:

trans-unit.source: However, if you have an existing key in a .pem file saved as local file in a file named softkey.pem that you want to upload to Azure Key Vault, type the following to import the key from the .PEM file, which protects the key by software in the Key Vault service:
trans-unit.target: However, if you have an existing key in a .pem file saved as local file in a file named softkey.pem that you want to upload to Azure Key Vault, type the following to import the key from the .PEM file, which protects the key by software in the Key Vault service:

trans-unit.source: You can now reference the key that you created or uploaded to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.
trans-unit.target: You can now reference the key that you created or uploaded to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.

trans-unit.source: Use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey/cgacf4f763ar42ffb0a1gca546aygd87** to get this specific version.
trans-unit.target: Use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey/cgacf4f763ar42ffb0a1gca546aygd87** to get this specific version.

trans-unit.source: To add a secret to the vault, which is a password named SQLPassword and that has the value of Pa$$w0rd to Azure Key Vault, type the following:
trans-unit.target: To add a secret to the vault, which is a password named SQLPassword and that has the value of Pa$$w0rd to Azure Key Vault, type the following:

trans-unit.source: You can now reference this password that you added to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.
trans-unit.target: You can now reference this password that you added to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.

trans-unit.source: Use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword/90018dbb96a84117a0d2847ef8e7189d** to get this specific version.
trans-unit.target: Use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword/90018dbb96a84117a0d2847ef8e7189d** to get this specific version.

trans-unit.source: Let's view the key or secret that you just created:
trans-unit.target: Let's view the key or secret that you just created:

trans-unit.source: To view your key, type: `azure keyvault key list --vault-name 'ContosoKeyVault'`
trans-unit.target: To view your key, type: `azure keyvault key list --vault-name 'ContosoKeyVault'`

trans-unit.source: To view your secret, type: `azure keyvault secret list -–vault-name 'ContosoKeyVault'`
trans-unit.target: To view your secret, type: `azure keyvault secret list -–vault-name 'ContosoKeyVault'`

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: This step would usually be done by a developer, on a separate computer.
trans-unit.target: This step would usually be done by a developer, on a separate computer.

trans-unit.source: It is not specific to Azure Key Vault but is included here, for completeness.
trans-unit.target: It is not specific to Azure Key Vault but is included here, for completeness.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] To complete the tutorial, your account, the vault, and the application that you will register in this step must all be in the same Azure directory.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] To complete the tutorial, your account, the vault, and the application that you will register in this step must all be in the same Azure directory.

trans-unit.source: Applications that use a key vault must authenticate by using a token from Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Applications that use a key vault must authenticate by using a token from Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: To do this, the owner of the application must first register the application in their Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: To do this, the owner of the application must first register the application in their Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the end of registration, the application owner gets the following values:
trans-unit.target: At the end of registration, the application owner gets the following values:

trans-unit.source: An **Application ID** (also known as a Client ID) and **authentication key** (also known as the shared secret).
trans-unit.target: An **Application ID** (also known as a Client ID) and **authentication key** (also known as the shared secret).

trans-unit.source: The application must present both of these values to Azure Active Directory, to get a token.
trans-unit.target: The application must present both of these values to Azure Active Directory, to get a token.

trans-unit.source: How the application is configured to do this depends on the application.
trans-unit.target: How the application is configured to do this depends on the application.

trans-unit.source: For the Key Vault sample application, the application owner sets these values in the app.config file.
trans-unit.target: For the Key Vault sample application, the application owner sets these values in the app.config file.

trans-unit.source: To register the application in Azure Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: To register the application in Azure Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click **Active Directory**, and then select the directory in which you will register your application.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click **Active Directory**, and then select the directory in which you will register your application.

trans-unit.source: Note: You must select the same directory that contains the Azure subscription with which you created your key vault.
trans-unit.target: Note: You must select the same directory that contains the Azure subscription with which you created your key vault.

trans-unit.source: If you do not know which directory this is, click **Settings**, identify the subscription with which you created your key vault, and note the name of the directory displayed in the last column.
trans-unit.target: If you do not know which directory this is, click **Settings**, identify the subscription with which you created your key vault, and note the name of the directory displayed in the last column.

trans-unit.source: Click **APPLICATIONS**.
trans-unit.target: Click **APPLICATIONS**.

trans-unit.source: If no apps have been added to your directory, this page will show only the **Add an App** link.
trans-unit.target: If no apps have been added to your directory, this page will show only the **Add an App** link.

trans-unit.source: Click the link, or alternatively, you can click the **ADD** on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click the link, or alternatively, you can click the **ADD** on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: In the **ADD APPLICATION** wizard, on the **What do you want to do?** page, click **Add an application my organization is developing**.
trans-unit.target: In the **ADD APPLICATION** wizard, on the **What do you want to do?** page, click **Add an application my organization is developing**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Tell us about your application** page, specify a name for your application and select **WEB APPLICATION AND/OR WEB API** (the default).
trans-unit.target: On the **Tell us about your application** page, specify a name for your application and select **WEB APPLICATION AND/OR WEB API** (the default).

trans-unit.source: Click the Next icon.
trans-unit.target: Click the Next icon.

trans-unit.source: On the **App properties** page, specify the **SIGN-ON URL** and **APP ID URI** for your web application.
trans-unit.target: On the **App properties** page, specify the **SIGN-ON URL** and **APP ID URI** for your web application.

trans-unit.source: If your application does not have these values, you can make them up for this step (for example, you could specify http://test1.contoso.com for both boxes).
trans-unit.target: If your application does not have these values, you can make them up for this step (for example, you could specify http://test1.contoso.com for both boxes).

trans-unit.source: It does not matter if these sites exist; what is important is that the app ID URI for each application is different for every application in your directory.
trans-unit.target: It does not matter if these sites exist; what is important is that the app ID URI for each application is different for every application in your directory.

trans-unit.source: The directory uses this string to identify your app.
trans-unit.target: The directory uses this string to identify your app.

trans-unit.source: Click the Complete icon to save your changes in the wizard.
trans-unit.target: Click the Complete icon to save your changes in the wizard.

trans-unit.source: On the Quick Start page, click **CONFIGURE**.
trans-unit.target: On the Quick Start page, click **CONFIGURE**.

trans-unit.source: Scroll to the **keys** section, select the duration, and then click **SAVE**.
trans-unit.target: Scroll to the **keys** section, select the duration, and then click **SAVE**.

trans-unit.source: The page refreshes and now shows a key value.
trans-unit.target: The page refreshes and now shows a key value.

trans-unit.source: You must configure your application with this key value and the **CLIENT ID** value.
trans-unit.target: You must configure your application with this key value and the **CLIENT ID** value.

trans-unit.source: (Instructions for this configuration will be application-specific.)
trans-unit.target: (Instructions for this configuration will be application-specific.)

trans-unit.source: Copy the client ID value from this page, which you will use in the next step to set permissions on your vault.
trans-unit.target: Copy the client ID value from this page, which you will use in the next step to set permissions on your vault.

trans-unit.source: Authorize the application to use the key or secret
trans-unit.target: Authorize the application to use the key or secret

trans-unit.source: To authorize the application to access the key or secret in the vault, use the `azure keyvault set-policy` command.
trans-unit.target: To authorize the application to access the key or secret in the vault, use the `azure keyvault set-policy` command.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your vault name is ContosoKeyVault and the application you want to authorize has a client ID of 8f8c4bbd-485b-45fd-98f7-ec6300b7b4ed, and you want to authorize the application to decrypt and sign with keys in your vault, then run the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, if your vault name is ContosoKeyVault and the application you want to authorize has a client ID of 8f8c4bbd-485b-45fd-98f7-ec6300b7b4ed, and you want to authorize the application to decrypt and sign with keys in your vault, then run the following:

trans-unit.source: If you want to authorize that same application to read secrets in your vault, run the following:
trans-unit.target: If you want to authorize that same application to read secrets in your vault, run the following:

trans-unit.source: If you want to use a hardware security module (HSM)
trans-unit.target: If you want to use a hardware security module (HSM)

trans-unit.source: For added assurance, you can import or generate keys in hardware security modules (HSMs) that never leave the HSM boundary.
trans-unit.target: For added assurance, you can import or generate keys in hardware security modules (HSMs) that never leave the HSM boundary.

trans-unit.source: The HSMs are FIPS 140-2 Level 2 validated.
trans-unit.target: The HSMs are FIPS 140-2 Level 2 validated.

trans-unit.source: If this requirement doesn't apply to you, skip this section and go to [Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets](#delete-the-key-vault-and-associated-keys-and-secrets).
trans-unit.target: If this requirement doesn't apply to you, skip this section and go to [Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets](#delete-the-key-vault-and-associated-keys-and-secrets).

trans-unit.source: To create these HSM-protected keys, you must have a vault subscription that supports HSM-protected keys.
trans-unit.target: To create these HSM-protected keys, you must have a vault subscription that supports HSM-protected keys.

trans-unit.source: When you create the keyvault, add the 'sku' parameter:
trans-unit.target: When you create the keyvault, add the 'sku' parameter:

trans-unit.source: You can add software-protected keys (as shown earlier) and HSM-protected keys to this vault.
trans-unit.target: You can add software-protected keys (as shown earlier) and HSM-protected keys to this vault.

trans-unit.source: To create an HSM-protected key, set the Destination parameter to 'HSM':
trans-unit.target: To create an HSM-protected key, set the Destination parameter to 'HSM':

trans-unit.source: You can use the following command to import a key from a .pem file on your computer.
trans-unit.target: You can use the following command to import a key from a .pem file on your computer.

trans-unit.source: This command imports the key into HSMs in the Key Vault service:
trans-unit.target: This command imports the key into HSMs in the Key Vault service:

trans-unit.source: The next command imports a “bring your own key" (BYOK) package.
trans-unit.target: The next command imports a “bring your own key" (BYOK) package.

trans-unit.source: This lets you generate your key in your local HSM, and transfer it to HSMs in the Key Vault service, without the key leaving the HSM boundary:
trans-unit.target: This lets you generate your key in your local HSM, and transfer it to HSMs in the Key Vault service, without the key leaving the HSM boundary:

trans-unit.source: For more detailed instructions about how to generate this BYOK package, see [How to use HSM-Protected Keys with Azure Key Vault](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903624.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed instructions about how to generate this BYOK package, see [How to use HSM-Protected Keys with Azure Key Vault](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903624.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets
trans-unit.target: Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets

trans-unit.source: If you no longer need the key vault and the key or secret that it contains, you can delete the key vault by using the azure keyvault delete command:
trans-unit.target: If you no longer need the key vault and the key or secret that it contains, you can delete the key vault by using the azure keyvault delete command:

trans-unit.source: Or, you can delete an entire Azure resource group, which includes the key vault and any other resources that you included in that group:
trans-unit.target: Or, you can delete an entire Azure resource group, which includes the key vault and any other resources that you included in that group:

trans-unit.source: Other Azure Cross-Platform Command-line Interface Commands
trans-unit.target: Other Azure Cross-Platform Command-line Interface Commands

trans-unit.source: Other commands that you might useful for managing Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Other commands that you might useful for managing Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: This command lists a tabular display of all keys and selected properties:
trans-unit.target: This command lists a tabular display of all keys and selected properties:

trans-unit.source: This command displays a full list of properties for the specified key:
trans-unit.target: This command displays a full list of properties for the specified key:

trans-unit.source: This command lists a tabular display of all secret names and selected properties:
